slidelink.displaytext: No Two Sites are the Same

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to Web-Based Job Search, on online resource for job seekers.

Click the button to view a tutorial on course navigation. To skip the tutorial, click the Next button to begin.

•Menu Tab - Displays each screen in the course, with the current screen highlighted.
Users can navigate to any previously viewed material by clicking to highlight a screen title.
Sections can be expanded or collapsed.

•Closed Caption Tab - Displays the narrated audio.

•Volume Adjustment - The user can change the volume level of the narration.
If no speakers are available, the user may refer to the "Closed Caption" tab to read along, if preferred.

•Play/Pause Button - This button lets you choose to Play or Pause the course.
The Play button keeps the course moving forward.
The Pause button allows the user to temporarily stop the course.
If you exit the course, you will be prompted to resume where you left off.

•Replay Button – Will replay the current screen from the beginning.

•Previous and Next Buttons – Allow user to view previous material, or continue through the course.

If you don't have much computer experience, you may ask, “Why should I bother using the Internet for my job search? I found good employment long before the Internet was invented.” Here's the answer to your question. You should use the Internet to search for employment because employers use the Internet to search for employees.

Many employers require candidates to fill out applications online on their website. Why? Because it's easier and more efficient for them. Think about it. As an employer:

•I don't have to waste time with candidates coming to my office and asking for an application.

•I don't have to deal with sloppy handwriting.

•I save money by not having to have copies of blank applications on hand.

And one more thing…I want people who've kept their skills up to date and are technically savvy. I weed out candidates who can't fill out an online application.

Are you beginning to understand why a web-based job search is so important?

A web-based job search should include a number of resources:

•Basic search engines, which can be used to find information on virtually any subject,

•Job search engines, which can be used to find employment opportunities with a variety of employers,

•Company web sites that provide information about a specific company. They often advertise career opportunities and may require you to complete an online application.

•Finally, electronic networking tools like LinkedIn which can be used to connect to people who share a common interest or skill.

Before we look at these resources, let's talk about basic navigation on the Internet. If this is new to you, you need to know how to use the tools on your screen. Click on each tab to learn more.

•Toolbar: Provides quick access to functions that are commonly performed within a computer program.

•Address Bar: Allows you to enter the web address of a page you wish to visit. Use this box only if you know the address of the site you are seeking.

•Search Bar: Accesses the search engine. Use this bar to locate information on virtually any topic.

•Back/Forward Buttons: Moves you to and from screens you've previously viewed.

•Refresh: Reloads/ redisplays the current page.

•Favorites: Stores your favorite web pages on the computer, making it easier for you to find them later.

•Enter Key: Moves the cursor to the front of the next line when you're typing a document. Sometimes, the Enter Key is referred to as the Return Key. This key is also used to execute a command on your computer.

•Cursor: Gives a visual representation on the screen that allows you to specify where you want the text to be placed. The cursor is usually represented by a flashing vertical line or by a flashing box.

•Tab Key: Moves the cursor from one field to the next field when completing applications and profiles on the Internet.

•Icon: Uses a picture to represent a folder, program, or file.

•Maximize / Minimize: Increases or decreases the size of a window on your screen. Maximize increases the window to the full size of the screen. Minimize reduces the window and places it on the taskbar.

•Pull-Down Menu: Provides a way to access and view a list of optional information or commands when you're working with websites containing a lot of information.

•Scroll: Allows you to view the entire content of a screen by moving visual portions of the screen up, down, left, or right.

•Taskbar: Allows you to locate and activate computer programs using the Start button at the bottom left-hand portion of your screen. Also, you can open any program that has been minimized and placed on the taskbar.

You also need to know how to use email, whether it's with the Internet or not. If you don't have an email account, you can set up and use a free one on Hotmail, Yahoo, or Google. Let's look at an example from Yahoo.

Now, type yahoo.com into the Internet address window.

Click the mail feature near the upper left side of your screen.

Locate the box which reads “Sign in to Yahoo!”

At the bottom of the box, click “Create New Account.”

Type your first and last name in the appropriate field.

Yahoo will suggest several choices of Yahoo ID's. Each choice is built using elements of your name. Select your favorite choice as your Yahoo ID. This will become the first part of your email address.

Next, create a password. Your password must be at least six characters long but can't be more than 32 characters long. Do not use your name or your Yahoo ID as part of your password. Retype your password in the appropriate field to verify its accuracy.

Remember to write down your password and keep it in a safe place for future reference.

Now, complete the personal information:

•Birthday

•Gender

•Language

•Country, and

•Postal code (which is the same as your zip code).

Next, provide information within your account to be used in case you can't remember your password.

Don't forget to use the pulldown menu to select the appropriate country if you're using your mobile phone as a back-up contact.

Finally, click “Create my account.”

Create your email address by building it around your first and last names. If you have a common name, add a random number or variation which still makes it clear this is your name. For example, Anita.Job1@yahoo.com.

Remember that employers turn away from candidates who have unprofessional email addresses that contain sexual, religious, or political references. It's also a good idea to avoid references to age.
To send an email, sign in to your email account. Locate and double click the “Compose” option.

In the field marked “To,” type the address of the person who will receive the email.

In the field marked “Subject,” tell your reader what the email is about. For example, suppose you were writing an email to a friend, asking if she knew of any job openings at her workplace. Your subject line could read, “Looking for Work.”

Notice the CC and the BCC features.

“CC” stands for Carbon Copy. Use this feature when you want to send a copy of the email to someone in addition to the main reader. Keep in mind, the main reader can see the name and/or email address of everybody you place in the “CC” field.

“BCC” stands for Blind Carbon Copy. Use this feature when you want to send a copy of the email to an additional reader, and you don't want the main reader to see who has received a copy of the email.

The “Letter” field is the largest part of the email page. Use the space in this field to type your email message.

After you write your message, click “Send.” The date and time the email was sent will automatically be added to the message.

Now, let's take a look at your email folders, located on the left-hand side of your email screen.

The Inbox allows you to view messages other people have sent to you.

Email is displayed in chronological order, with the most recent email at the top of the list. Email you haven't read yet is displayed in bold letters. Notice how the message from William Epperson has not been read

Click on the email to read the message.
You can also view a copy of email messages you've sent. Simply double click on the “Sent” folder. Double click on the email you'd like to view, and the message appears.

You have other folders available to you, as well. The Drafts folder holds email messages which you have not finished writing.

The Spam folder holds electronic junk mail.

The Trash folder holds mail you have discarded by using the Delete function.

To view the email in any folder, simply double click on the folder.

A nice thing about email messages is you can attach all sorts of files to them. For example, let's say a potential employer asks you for a sample of your work (such as a report or illustration). You can create an email message and attach the report to your email message. The recipient gets a copy of both your message AND the report.

Let's see how sending an attachment works.
Attaching a document is easy, with a little practice. After you finish writing your email, click on the Attachment feature.
A new window appears. Search through the items in the window until you locate the file you want to attach. Remember to use the scroll bar in the new window to reveal more files, if needed.
Here's the right file. It's labeled Resume, Ric Byrd. Double click on the file, and it attaches to the email.
You now have an email, along with its attachment. All you need to do now is click on “Send.” And by the way, you can attach multiple files to a single email.
When you use email, remember that no two websites are the same. Your email attachment may appear differently depending on the email service you use.

Now that you understand Internet and email navigation, let's look at the job search resources we mentioned earlier. The first type is general search engines - which are easy to find and use. Almost everyone has heard of Google.

To find any of these search engines, go to the address field of your web browser and type the name of the search engine followed by “.com.” For instance, type google.com and press the Enter key. When the Google page displays, you'll see a search box.

Type something in the search box. For example type “jobs in Indianapolis” or “Duke Energy” or “Good companies to work for in Indianapolis.”

Basic search engines are great because you can type in just about anything and get a response. There are no rules!

Job search engines, on the other hand, are specifically related to job search. Contrary to popular belief, these job search engines were not created so you could find a job. They were created so employers could fill positions. There are job search engines for national, state, and local employment opportunities.

Some of the more popular national job search engines are Monster, Indeed and Careerbuilder. These sites allow you to search for jobs across the nation and overseas. You can use a variety of criteria including occupation keywords, job titles, and locations to narrow your search. Many of these sites have helpful job and career information, too.

An example of a state-specific job search engine is www.workintexas.com. You can use this site to search for jobs in Texas by employer, education, or skills. If you need help, your local workforce development professional can show you how to register or complete the application.

An example of a local job search engine is HoustonJobs.com.

You can also use national and state job search engines to search locally by entering specific location information. For example,

•careerbuilder.com,

•indeed.com, and

•simplyhired.com all have Houston-specific sites.

Regardless of the type of job search engine you use - national, state, or local -- it's a good idea to create a profile. A profile allows you to maximize your productivity within the site. It saves your important information so you won't have to type it over and over again.

You should create a profile for each job search engine you use.

To create a profile, you'll need to generate a “user name” and a password. You'll use your email address to send and receive correspondence.

Finally, you can search for employment opportunities on individual company or business web sites such as:

·Chevron

·Waste Management

·University of Texas

No two company websites are the same, and they tend to use different terminology to list their job opportunities. Look for clues to navigate your way through the site. For example, Chevron's website lists job opportunities under “About.” Waste Management’s website lists its job opportunities under “Inside WM” University of Texas requires you to click on “Faculty & Staff” then “Human Resources,” then ”Apply for a Job.” You just need to explore a little - almost all large businesses have job portals on their websites now.

Because networking is still the best way to find a job, electronic networking (or social media) sites are an important Internet resource. Although you may have heard of Facebook and Twitter, the best site for professional networking is LinkedIn.

LinkedIn is a great way to network your way into job opportunities. Here are some facts about this site:

•LinkedIn has over 575 million users, with more than 260 million monthly active users.

•The average LinkedIn member is between 25-34 years old.

•44% of LinkedIn users take home more than $75,000 per year, which is above the national median in the US.

•Every one of the Fortune 500 companies has employees on LinkedIn.

•About 10 million small business owners are on LinkedIn.

You should create and use a LinkedIn account to:

•Build a profile that introduces you to others professionally,

•Make connections to people with whom you can share information about your job search and from whom you can gain career insights,

•Join LinkedIn Groups to explore new ideas within your career through online group discussions, and

•Look for job opportunities and gather information on the employers listed on LinkedIn.

Open a LinkedIn account and begin creating your profile by going to the address bar and typing www.linkedin.com.

To create an account, type your first and last name in the appropriate fields.

Type your email address into the appropriate field.

Next, create a password to use when you log back in to your LinkedIn account. Your password will need to be at least six characters long.

Then click “Join Now.”

You're now ready to create a LinkedIn profile following their user-friendly steps!

Your LinkedIn profile should tell readers who you are and (hopefully) capture their interest. Be sure to include information about your past experiences, your particular skills, your education, and professional organizations to which you belong. Include a professional headshot photo of yourself.

Now, it's time to start making connections. Building a network in LinkedIn is like building a network anyplace else. Always start with people you know and trust. In general, start with your family and friends first. Then, move on to neighbors, acquaintances, and former co-workers and classmates.

You'll also want to network through any professional affiliations to which you belong - especially affiliations attached to your chosen career or industry. If you're a trucker, for example, consider networking with a long-distance hauling affiliate or group.

You can join groups on LinkedIn too, with members who have similar interests and backgrounds.

LinkedIn identifies groups you may like.

Find out about a group by clicking on the group's name.

Information about the group appears. You request to join the group by simply clicking “Join Group”.

You can even look for jobs on LinkedIn.

Click on the “Search for Jobs” feature. You can search by job title, keyword, or company name.
As you can see, there are many tools and resources on LinkedIn to help you make the right connections. Once you've created your profile, don't be afraid to do some exploring!

Hopefully, we've convinced you to use web-based tools as part of your job search plan. These tools should include:

•Basic search engines, such as Google, Bing, or Ask

•Job search engines - national, state, and local,

•Company websites, and

•Electronic networking sites like LinkedIn.

With a little practice, you'll be searching for jobs on the Internet in no time…and you'll probably be surprised at the results. Good luck!
